newsitem.title: USA: Edison extends labor contracts, raises wages.
newsitem.headline: Edison extends labor contracts, raises wages.

text.p: Edison International's Southern California Edison and its two largest labor unions announced Friday the extension of general labor contracts for two more years to December 31, 1998.

The agreements are subject to ratification by members of Local 47 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) and Local 246 of the Utility Workers Union of America (UWUA), the company said in a statement.
In addition to the time extensions, the utility said the agreements with both unions include general across-the-board wage increases of 3 percent for 1997 and 3.5 percent for 1998.
The utility said the unions agreed to work with Edison to find ways to deal with changes in contract terms that are likely to become necessary as the industry moves toward competition.

"Traditional contract negotiations may not be the best way to bring about needed modifications in work practices in light of the pace of change, complexity of issues and ongoing evolution of the electric utility business," said Edison President Stephen E. Frank.

UWUA members may be affected by divestiture of power plants because of restructuring, and issues related to providing operation and maintenance services to purchasers of Edison plants are expected to arise over the next two years.

"Achieving success in this new environment may lead to unavoidable changes in employee work practices and work status," said Rae Sanborn, Business Manager of IBEW Local 47, which represents employees in the electrical transmission and distribution business lines of the utility. "However, by working together on a continuing basis, we hope also to build a more secure future for union members who remain with Edison."
The members of both unions account for about 45 percent of Edison's work force of more than 14,000 employees.
